text:
Our scout is a top football expert who attends matches each week searching for the next star.
He brings you his verdict in Sportsmail.
This week it is Sunderland's Joel Asoro under the microscope...
Sunderland's promising striker Joel Asoro has lightning speed and can escape defenders
JOEL ASORO FACTFILE Name: Joel Asoro
Club: Sunderland
Position: Striker
Age: 17
Value: £1million
2016-17 appearances: 4
Goals: 0
WHAT HAS HE GOT?
Sunderland have had little joy this season but in Swedish-born Joel Asoro they could have a striker to partner Jermain Defoe.
Asoro is lively and certainly makes central defenders concentrate.
He is not lazy — indeed his closing down is excellent, especially when the second striker was having to drop deeper as his team came under pressure.
He has excellent speed — Asoro is possibly the quickest forward I have seen this season — and a surge to escape defenders.
Any ball played down the side, if his timing is right and the pass accurate, gives him a chance of getting clear. He has the perfect physique for a front man and can resist a strong challenge.
In the first half of a recent game he competed well against a tall, imposing central defender. As the game progressed, his timing improved and he stopped the centre backs clearing properly. He was isolated as his team were forced back, but still a danger. He looks a finisher, thudding a shot against the bar after a brilliant twist and turn.
He shows determination and I was impressed when, after taking a heavy knock, he staggered back on, becoming a threat again. It's a strong character trait. He has scored 21 goals in 30 appearances for Sweden's junior teams.
The Swedish-born striker has played in the EFL Cup for the Black Cats this season
WHAT DOES HE NEED?
His hold-up play was not overly tested but, when challenged with the ball played to his feet, he only retained the ball 50 per cent of the time.
The few crosses played into him were not accurate enough to show his heading qualities.
Primarily, he needs the confidence of boss David Moyes. Sunderland are in a relegation battle and, while Asoro is inexperienced, he has something about him. Why not throw him in? He could play without fear.
His pace can surprise defenders and he can share some of the front-line duties with Defoe.
